title: Clarification on terminology
text: diving terms, note use fonts site. Firstly, command object considered code shown code. example, typing “sum(+ b)” console shown sum(+ b). Likewise, functions always denoted code format, addition open closed parentheses. example, function “foo” denoted foo().

title: Clarification on terminology
text: R, variable refers name stored value. example: , .vector holds vector c(9, 10, 11) refer operations .vector. Sometimes programmers also refer .vector object since type object within syntax R. EPA API, variable refers desired data filtering characteristic URL request. example, URL, https://aqs.epa.gov/data/api/dailyData/byState?&email=youremail@domain.com&key=yourapikey&state=37 state considered variable URL since data queried according particular state. avoid confusion, always refer variables referring API API variable. dealing R variables, call object specifically call R data type like R list. example, tutorial, often times reference services variables. R objects (.e. list dataframe) loaded epair, R variable containing information EPA API.
code: my.vector <- c(9, 10, 11)

title: Clarification on terminology
text: wider world mathematics, parameter can mean value passed function. example, , b considered parameters function foo() since passed function inputs. EPA API, parameter codes. refer particular way API variable used. instance, taking look URL showed , https://aqs.epa.gov/data/api/dailyData/byState?&email=youremail@domain.com&key=yourapikey&state=37 see state = 37. , 37 parameter code state API variable, code must constructed particular way match API variable. Another example, following URL, https://aqs.epa.gov/data/api/dailyData/byState?&email=youremail@domain.com&key=yourapikey&state=37&bdate=20200101&edate=20200102&param=44201 note bdate API variable referring beginning date desired data. parameter code 20200101. Likewise, param API variable parameter code 44201. site, refer values passed function arguments parameter codes refer encoding value needed API variable.
code: foo(a, b)

previous_headings: How to install and load epair
title: Installation
text: Since GitHub, installing epair R devtools package straightforward.
code: library(devtools) devtools::install_github("GLOrozcoM/epair") library(epair)

previous_headings: How to install and load epair
title: Installation
text: alternative download epair files computer GitHub. can download . navigating parent folder epair directory, can use devtools.
code: devtools::install("epair") library(epair)

title: Setup
text: ’ll need acquire API key AQS. , epair provides function get.aqs.key() email parameter. calling get.aqs.key() check email obtain key. sure confirm account clicking link email acquiring key first time. epair uses .Renviron access email key making calls. simple way setup key email usethis package following command. usethis::edit_r_environ() open .Renviron file can store email key. MUST store key email using exactformat aqs_api_key=‘received_key’ aqs_email=‘youremail@domain.com’. Otherwise, package assume haven’t declared credentials. Note also need restart R ensure changes take effect. even restarting R, Sys.getenv(‘aqs_email’) returning null string, can also try setting variables Sys.setenv() command follows Sys.setenv(aqs_email = “youremail@domain.com”) Sys.setenv(aqs_api_key = “received_key”).

what: Checking if the API is running
title: Setup
text: queries automatically check API running. might make sense, however, check API making multiple queries. package allows make check easily.
code: is.API.running()

what: See what services the API offers
title: Making your first call
text: sure load package starting! outset, may know exactly want API. can start taking look services object included package. services object R list contains information service offered EPA API use . just want see list services offered, can try want see description particular service, may type name select services. example MetaData service shown . Using RStudio’s smart variable selection, simply typing services$ open service select along useful information service.  Becoming familiar services object can help make calls. Navigating services page, talk depth services object.
code: library(epair) names(services) ##  [1] "MetaData"                                               ##  [2] "List"                                                   ##  [3] "Monitors"                                               ##  [4] "Sample Data"                                            ##  [5] "Daily Summary Data"                                     ##  [6] "Annual Summary Data"                                    ##  [7] "Quality Assurance - Blanks Data"                        ##  [8] "Quality Assurance - Collocated Assessments"             ##  [9] "Quality Assurance - Flow Rate Verifications"            ## [10] "Quality Assurance - Flow Rate Audits"                   ## [11] "Quality Assurance - One Point Quality Control Raw Data" ## [12] "Quality Assurance - PEP Audits" services[["MetaData"]]$Description ## [1] "Returns information about the API.  Is it available/up?  What are the meanings of the fields in my returned data?Recent and planned changes, etc."

title: Making your first call
text: example, attempt list parameter codes associated states US.

title: Making your first call
text: haven’t already read Anatomy API request, recommend . post explains call made may help making calls. Remember set authentication first! package automatically includes base call (base API site authentication). query, need find appropriate get function service, manually provide endpoint perform.call() (see can determine endpoint see Finding endpoints page).

title: Making your first call
text: reduce difficulty finding specific endpoint API call, collection specific get functions service filter combination. trying find state parameter codes, return states respective FIPS codes. get function service provide R list Header Data component. Header contains information call useful determining call went . get actual data called (states parameter codes), use Data component result.
code: result <- get_state_fips() result$Header$status result$Header$request_time result$Data

title: Making your first call
text: want make call manually, need determine appropriate endpoint type query wish make. Recall ’re looking parameter codes associated state US. first look services, select List’s description see appropriate service use.  seems like perfect service use find state parameter codes. select List, see multiple Filters available listing.  looks like States appropriate option . shows us endpoint use required variables. Since email key always included calls, need get endpoint make call. determining endpoint, can make call using perform.call(). perform.call() function provide R list structure output get functions. Alternatively, want original output API, perform.call.raw() make request, provide request results raw JSON format.
code: services$List$Description ## [1] "Provides information you need to construct other queries.  Valid values for the required variables: parameter code, state code, etc.  (See below.)" services$List$Filters$States ## $Endpoint ## [1] "list/states" ##  ## $RequiredVariables ## [1] "email, key" ##  ## $OptionalVariables ## [1] "" ##  ## $Example ## [1] "Returns a list of the states and their FIPS codes used for constructing other requests:https://aqs.epa.gov/data/api/list/states?email=test@aqs.api&key=test" endpoint <- services$List$Filters$States$Endpoint result <- perform.call(endpoint = endpoint) raw.result <- perform.call.raw(endpoint = endpoint)

title: Make a more complex call
text: start , suppose want find counties respective parameter codes exist North Carolina. can use services object, check List service Making first call.  looks like Counties state filter appropriate since ’re trying determine county parameter codes North Carolina. specific service filter can done get_counties_in_state(). get function defined arguments required optional variable. functions documentation variables available Reference page. can add variables passing arguments user friendly functions. Notice required variable state.fips. Since ’re looking counties North Carolina, can use parameter code North Carolina entry state. able determine parameter codes states Making first call look output find parameter code North Carolina 37. example, know specific state code North Carolina, pass argument corresponding function.
code: result <- get_counties_in_state(state.fips = '37')

title: Make a more complex call
text: Similar single variables, higher level functions require parameters service choice. Suppose, instance, ’re interested finding daily ozone data North Carolina, starting January 1, 2020 ending January 2, 2020, determined correct parameter codes API variable (please see Navigating API services Figuring API variables understand go determining proper parameter codes variables).
code: result <- get_daily_summary_in_state(bdate = '20200101',                                       edate = '20200102',                                      state.fips = '37',                                      param = '44201')

title: Make a more complex call
text: Similar , can also go placing call another method manually finding endpoint. , can locate endpoint services object, check List service, select filter looking . Now, can perform call putting together endpoint listing counties state particular state ’re interested. Note specified additional variables ’d adding variables = state.code, inserted API variable name name = state function. alternative simply declare parameter code API variable name follows.
code: services$List$Filters$`Counties by State` ## $Endpoint ## [1] "list/countiesByState" ##  ## $RequiredVariables ## [1] "email, key, state" ##  ## $OptionalVariables ## [1] "" ##  ## $Example ## [1] "Example; returns all counties in North Carolina:https://aqs.epa.gov/data/api/list/countiesByState?email=test@aqs.api&key=test&state=37" endpoint <- services$List$Filters$`Counties by State`$Endpoint state.code <- '37' result <- perform.call(endpoint = endpoint, variables = state.code, name = "state") endpoint <- services$List$Filters$`Counties by State`$Endpoint state <- '37' result <- perform.call(endpoint = endpoint, variables = state)

title: Make a more complex call
text: case multiple variables, can make list variables pass list perform.call() second argument. , ’re interested finding daily ozone data North Carolina, starting January 1, 2020 ending January 2, 2020, determined correct parameter codes API variable. , create list appropriate API variable names declared parameter codes.
code: endpoint <- 'dailyData/byState' variable.list <- list("state" = '37',                        "bdate" = '20200101',                        "edate" = '20200102',                        "param" = '44201') result <- perform.call(endpoint = endpoint, variables = variable.list)

title: Make a more complex call
text: Calling large dataset frequently can take time load time, can cache data storing user’s specified directory convenience. get function perform.call() can specify argument whether call cached directory call saved . example, plan use daily ozone data North Carolina January 1, 2020 March 1, 2020 many times , can specify want cache data user friendly functions. similarly, cache data using endpoint method. Without specification arguments, get perform.call() functions default always cache call directory “~/epair/cache” based current working directory.
code: result <- get_daily_summary_in_state(bdate = '20200101',                                       edate = '20200102',                                      state.fips = '37',                                      param = '44201',                                      cached = TRUE,                                      cache_directory = "~/epair/cache") endpoint <- 'dailyData/byState' variable.list <- list("state" = '37',                        "bdate" = '20200101',                        "edate" = '20200301',                        "param" = '44201') result <- perform.call(endpoint = endpoint,                         variables = variable.list,                         cached = TRUE,                         cache_directory = "~/epair/cache")

title: Summary
text: Make call appropriate get function service. call requires single variable, declare variable variable name pass argument, directly pass argument. call requires multiple variables, pass variable ’s corresponding argument.
code: result <- get_state_fips() result <- get_counties_in_state(state.fips = 'value') result <- get_annual_summary_in_state(bdate = "value.one",                                       edate = "value.two",                                       state.fips = "value.three",                                       param = "value.four")

title: Summary
text: Determine endpoint service (possibly services object). Make call perform.call(). call requires single variable, declare variable API variable name pass second argument perform.call(). , specify name API variable third argument. call requires multiple variables, make list pass second argument perform.call(). , specify names parameter codes second argument.
code: endpoint <- 'APIEndpoint' result <- perform.call(endpoint) variable <- "value" result <- perform.call(endpoint, variable) variable.code <- "value" result <- perform.call(endpoint, variable.code, name = "API variable name") variables <- list(variable.one = "value.one",                   variable.two = "value.two",                   variable.three = "value.three") result <- perform.call(endpoint, variables) variables <- list("value.one", "value.two", "value.three") result <- perform.call(endpoint,                         variables,                        name = list("variable.one", "variable.two", "variable.three"))

title: Finding endpoints
text: endpoints object comes loaded epair. endpoints vector provides EPA API endpoints use. can see calling endpoints. “manually” find particular endpoint looking similarities API service endpoint name. example, get annual data state, ’s easy see annualData/byState right endpoint use.
code: endpoints ##  [1] "signup"                           "metaData/isAvailable"             ##  [3] "metaData/fieldsByService"         "metaData/fieldsByService"         ##  [5] "metaData/issues"                  "list/states"                      ## title: Finding endpoints
text: Visually sifting endpoints can confusing another approach services object. know API service want use, finding corresponding endpoint straightforward. example, let’s suppose want get daily summary data particular county. , using services object can see endpoint follows. Select Daily Summary Data services.  select appropriate filter, case, County.  , select Endpoint.  fact, endpoints service can found using general template.
code: services$`Daily Summary Data`$Filters$`By County`$Endpoint ## [1] "dailyData/byCounty" services$ServiceName$Filters$SpecificFilter$Endpoint

title: Navigating API Services
text: services object comes loaded package. R list containing comprehensive information service offered EPA API. can see services available using names(). Alternatively, using RStudio’s smart variable selection, can type services$ see available services.
code: names(services) ##  [1] "MetaData"                                               ##  [2] "List"                                                   ##  [3] "Monitors"                                               ##  [4] "Sample Data"                                            ##  [5] "Daily Summary Data"                                     ##  [6] "Annual Summary Data"                                    ##  [7] "Quality Assurance - Blanks Data"                        ##  [8] "Quality Assurance - Collocated Assessments"             ##  [9] "Quality Assurance - Flow Rate Verifications"            ## [10] "Quality Assurance - Flow Rate Audits"                   ## [11] "Quality Assurance - One Point Quality Control Raw Data" ## [12] "Quality Assurance - PEP Audits"

title: Navigating API Services
text: can also see description service. helps determine service use. example, suppose want find hourly data particular state. Perhaps data contained daily summary can check description.  description suggests hourly data may used produce values, may necessarily get hourly data. try different service description.  service seems appropriate need. specifically mentions hourly data might even offer finer grain data. general, find description service, can type following.
code: services$`Daily Summary Data`$Description ## [1] "Returns data summarized at the daily level.  All daily summaries are calculated on midnight to midnight basis inlocal time.  Variables returned include date, mean value, maximum value, etc." services$`Sample Data`$Description ## [1] "Returns sample data - the finest grain data reported to EPA.  Usually hourly, sometimes 5-minute, 12-hour, etc. This service is available in several geographic selections based on geography: site, county, state, CBSA (core based statistical area, a grouping of counties), or latitude/longitude bounding box." service$ServiceName$Description

title: Navigating API Services
text: API services also component called filter. refers filter applied desired data. example, want find information weather monitors, specify monitors state vs county. services object contains Filters component lets user find final data can filtered. Using weather monitors example, can see filters available follows. , can use servics$Monitors$Filters$ see available filters.  Filters component services object contains information might need make call. endpoint, required API variables, optional API variables (appropriate), URL example call. general, see available filters, can type following: , using RStudio’s smart variable selection:
code: names(services$Monitors$Filters) ## [1] "By Site"   "By County" "By State"  "By Box"    "By CBSA" names(services$ServiceName$Filters) services$ServiceName$Filters$

title: Navigating API Services
text: seeing filter use, can see requirements make call. mentioned , Filters component contains endpoint, required API variable, optional API variable, example URL. helps trying build call package. instance, say want find annual data state US. can look filters annual data service see build call. general, can find information making call using specific filter follows:
code: services$`Annual Summary Data`$Filters$`By State` ## $Endpoint ## [1] "annualData/byState" ##  ## $RequiredVariables ## [1] "email, key, param, bdate, edate, state" ##  ## $OptionalVariables ## [1] "cbdate,cedate" ##  ## $Example ## [1] "Example; returns all benzene annual summaries from North Carolina collected for 1995:https://aqs.epa.gov/data/api/annualData/byState?email=test@aqs.api&key=test&param=45201&bdate=19950515&edate=19950515&state=37" services$ServiceName$Filters$SpecificFilter

title: EPA Data Helper for R
text: package designed aid getting data Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) API https://aqs.epa.gov/aqsweb/documents/data_api.html.

title: EPA Data Helper for R
text: epair package helps determine data want get data EPA API. provides loaded variables help navigate services API, simple way query data. Broadly, can explore possible calls typing epair::get_ seeing autocomplete offers R. functions require start end date along geographical boundary type (like CBSA code bounding box). details, recommend looking help docs ?epair::get_[type]() function ’re interested using see exact required params.

title: EPA Data Helper for R
text: can download package simply using r-universe. Alternativately, can download latest release repo using devtools. , download files, working directory run following. epair depends httr making data calls rvest creating variables loaded package. recommend httr installed (automatically taken care package dependencies), installing rvest ’re curious package variables made.
code: install.packages("epair", repos = "https://ropensci.r-universe.dev") devtools::install_github("ropensci/epair") devtools::install("ropensci/epair")

title: EPA Data Helper for R
text: Note currently single call AQS allows maximum single year’s worth data. ’ll need create separate calls get multiple year’s worth data.

title: EPA Data Helper for R
text: may want check ropenaq instead depending goals behind study. ropenaq R wrapper accessing OpenAQ API - see website . differences: epair get data single source (EPA AQS API), ropenaq useful ’re trying compare data different sources. ’re interested data US , epair appropriate choice. locations across world, ropenaq work better. epair’s data source offer granularity OpenAQ US data. EPA AQS API can give 500 parameters/pollutants interest (opposed OpenAQ’s 5), county level coverage, unaggregated raw data. default, OpenAQ give aggregated data ’re interested aggregations, OpenAQ way go.
